Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
FOM 722 – 08D – Treatment Plans – Agreements and signatures
Treatment Plans – Required Participation (PATP)
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain signatures from the following
individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when sibling in care are placed apart.
• Parents who are a member of a participating household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youths and caregivers must check yes or no for the following
when signing the treatment plan.
• I have participated in the development of the case service plan and the parent agency
service plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Agreement
Plan to review, and I will have the opportunity to express my disagreement with the Case
Service Plan Parent Agency Treatment Plan when the information is presented to court.
Three of three youth case files reviewed (thirteen PATP’s) were either missing required
PATP signatures, signatures not obtained within 30 days of the report due date and/or
boxes not checked and missing dates of the signatures.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted three acceptable corrective action plans during this
period under review. The renewal inspection report dated 5/9/2022, and the
CAP was accepted on 5/17/2022. The agency was in non-compliance with
Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home and DHHS FOM Policy 722-08E Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary. The agency is following their
corrective action plan as there was no noncompliance during this inspection
period.
The agency had two special investigations during this reporting period.
SI#2023C0000116 report dated on 4/6/23, and the CAP was accepted on
4/19/23. The agency received citations with Rules 400.12207, Staff
Responsibilities, 400.12409, Education policy and Rule 400.12413, Medical
and Dental policy. The agency has not had any other citations with these rules
during this reporting period.
SI#2023C0000295 report dated 5/4/23 and the CAP was accepted on 5/31/23.
The agency received citations with Rules 400.12419 Initial service plans and
400.12420, Updated service plans. The agency did not have any citations with
these rules during this reporting inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
3

The Chief Administrator reported in the entrance meeting held on 7/5/2023, that
the Supervisors and Directors meet weekly to share barriers, potential barriers and
successes to ensure compliance and brainstorm strategies to improve functions.
The information is shared with the team during weekly team meeting and
individually during monthly supervision. In addition, the Quality Departments send
monthly scorecards to identify trends and assist with audits.
Financial Overview
All audit of all financial accounts and budget for the fiscal year were reviewed. No
financial concerns were identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff interviewed reported that the agency has gone through a lot of
administrative changes, but the staff is adapting to change and learning the
different style that comes with the changes. Overall, the staff feel very supported
by their coworkers, supervisors, and administrator. The staff reported for staff
morale they participate each month in a national day where they get to mingle with
one another to reduce stress. They provided examples of playing bingo during
lunch, eating together for team building games and to discuss cases. All staff
interviewed stated they love working for the agency.
There were no youth interviewed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment. Case files are
stored in locked rooms/cabinets which prevent unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
4

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Ennis Center for Children - Howell continue on their regular
license.
